channel.title: Quin7et's Personal Website
channel.description: Recent content on Quin7et's Personal Website

item.title: Virginia: Perfect In form, Lost In Spirit
item.description: Preamble Eurogamer’s review of Thirty Flights of Loving states: “This is a game that packs more narrative punch into its first startling jump-cut than most can muster across an entire campaign.” Virginia, unfortunately, falls into the latter. Despite its effort to become Thirty Flight’s “full-length successor,” an overt ending credit tribute would not save Virginia from being a drawn-out, vapid hollow of its predecessor. Because of Virginia’s self-identification as an interactive movie rather than a game, it naturally fails to live up to Thirty Flight’s name - to push beyond the boundary of video game narrative techniques.

item.title: Things I Learned From the GMTK Game Jam
item.description: That’s when I realized, I was trying to make an IMPRESSIVE game, rather than a FUN one (which probably says a lot about my insecurities). I am NOT known for actually finishing my projects. Contrary to popular belief, creativity is NOT a rare talent. It’s not even a minority trait. Literally everyone is able to come up with an abundance of ideas, some of which are actually quite practical and executable.

item.title: About
item.description: I am Quin7et (pronounced “quintet”), a writer and a game developer. I made Campfire for Ludum Dare 50. I translated this Devil Daggers guide by Braden. I have translated a few entries (into Chinese) on the SCP Foundation. I wrote a short fiction published on Science Fiction World when I was 17. You’ve probably noticed that I didn’t link it. The reason being that I am not proud of it.
